messages: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:56): f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb, I actually agree with the sentence in the spec, for what it's worth
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:56): f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb, re: XML Maturity
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (10:57): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: yes you can agree with the sentence in the spec, but that doesn't mean that the sentence is appropriate in the spec
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:59): dunno, XHTML wouldn't work for authors and would not be as bacwards compatible as HTML
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (10:59): generally speaking
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:00): remember, 95% of the web is _syntactically_ incorrect
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:01): that doesn't make xhtml bad. It's why I propose the first paragraph, saying basically. "Be careful if you use XHTML".
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:01): instead of the sentence "XML sucks"
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:01): I think it will help to keep the tones friendly
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:02): and to avoid endless recurring debates
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:02): does it say XML sucks currently?
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:03): well yes, I see how people can read that.
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:03): and we had comments like this

e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:04): "Generally speaking, authors are discouraged from trying to use XML on the Web, because XML has much stricter syntax rules than the "HTML5" variant described above, and is relatively newer and therefore less mature."
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:04): is what it says
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:05): we should not discourgared anything
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:06): and this will raise the hair of more than one persons "and is relatively newer and therefore less mature."
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:06): I have already said what I had to say
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:06): Practically speaking, that statement will likely never survive LC comments.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:07): I agree with Karl. I think the decision to use XHTML or HTML should be up to the author, the spec should only give advise on technical issues
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:07): Well put.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:08): Except that instead of just advice, I would say it should give objection descriptions of conformant UA behavior.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:09): fwiw, I don't care much about whether it stays in the spec, it's just that I agree with the sentence
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:09): "objection descriptions"? Do you mean objective?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:09): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 - yeah. Freudian slip there :)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:09): what it says is pretty objective, both statements are factually correct
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:10): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 - great. Keep it in there then. If it's objective, then nobody can take issue with it of course.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:10): why not?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:11): people take issue with most things
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (11:11): indeed, you are doing right now ;) birthday party too long?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:11): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 - exactly
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (11:12): the spec may be be technically objective as-is, but it's just not worth debating the issue with those who object.  It's easier to just change the wording.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:12): So why give them more ammunition?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:12): amen
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:12): We have much more important battles to fight here.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:13): Providing the peanut gallery with more stuff to chime in on is maybe not too prudent.

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:16): Anyway, to point out something really positive that's happened recently, note that a rep from Access (makers of NetFront browser) has joined the group and been posting to the list.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:17): and to <email/>, I see

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:18): The NetFront browser engine is used in embedded applications all over the place, so their participation will definitely help to provide a broader perspective on browsing use cases and requirements.
